title: 110_hr3234
content: The Act may be cited as the "HSA Improvement and Expansion Act of 2007" and includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "HSA Improvement and Expansion Act of 2007" includes provisions for health reimbursement arrangements, increased HSA contribution limits, purchasing health insurance from HSA accounts, special rules for medical expenses, Medicare provisions, eligibility for veterans benefits, allowing spouses to make catch-up contributions, and terminating FSAs and HRAs to fund HSAs. The "HSA Improvement and Expansion Act of 2007" includes provisions for health reimbursement arrangements, increased HSA contribution limits, purchasing health insurance from HSA accounts, special rules for medical expenses, Medicare provisions, eligibility for veterans benefits, allowing spouses to make catch-up contributions, and terminating FSAs and HRAs to fund HSAs. Amendments include disregarding certain coverage, adding a combined limit for contributions or credits to health reimbursement arrangements and spending arrangements. In the case of coverage under a flexible spending arrangement or health reimbursement arrangement, the requirements are met if the sum of the deduction amount under subsection (a), salary reduction amount elected by the individual, and employer contribution or credit allocated to the individual for the taxable year meets certain criteria. The requirements for coverage under a health reimbursement arrangement include the individual's permitted reimbursements not exceeding the annual deductible and out-of-pocket expenses for covered benefits. Exceptions apply for certain flexible spending arrangements. Certain flexible spending arrangements and health reimbursement arrangements that are restricted by the employer for coverage described in paragraph (1)(B) shall not be considered under subparagraph (A)(i)(II) and (A)(i)(III) respectively. Qualified HSA distributions are also excluded. Qualified HSA distributions from FSA and HRA terminations are not considered under certain subparagraphs. Coverage requirements for taxable years after December 31, 2012, are not met. Effective date for amendments is after December 31, 2007. SEC. 3 increases the annual HSA contribution limits to $4,500 for individuals and $9,000 for families, with a cost-of-living adjustment effective from calendar year 2007. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 allows the purchase of health insurance from HSA accounts. SEC. 4 allows the purchase of health insurance from HSA accounts, with amendments to qualified medical expenses and an effective date for insurance purchased after the enactment of the Act. Certain medical expenses incurred before establishment of account treated as qualified. An expense shall not fail to be treated as a qualified medical expense solely because it was incurred before the establishment of the health savings account if incurred during the 60-day period beginning on the date the high deductible health plan is first effective. An individual is considered eligible for a health savings account regardless of coverage under a high deductible health plan on the 1st day of the month. The effective date of the account is the date the high deductible health plan becomes effective after the enactment of this paragraph. The amendment applies to insurance purchased after the enactment date. Insurance purchased after the enactment of this Act in taxable years beginning after such date. SEC. 6. PROVISIONS RELATING TO MEDICARE. This section amends contribution limitations for Medicare eligible individuals and allows Medicare beneficiaries participating in Medicare Advantage MSA to contribute their own money. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Individuals eligible for veterans benefits for a service-connected disability. Individuals eligible for certain veterans benefits receiving hospital care or medical services for a service-connected disability are not considered covered under a health plan unless they are not eligible for care or services for any other condition. Effective date for amendments is after the enactment date. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Allow both spouses to make catch-up contributions to the same HSA account. The amendment allows both spouses over age 55 to contribute 200 percent of the usual amount to a health savings account if one spouse is not already a beneficiary. Effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment allows for distributions from a health savings account without requiring a grace period for unused amounts. Additionally, excess funds from a termination distribution can be deposited into a health flexible spending account or health reimbursement arrangement compatible with a health savings account. The amendment allows for distributions from a health savings account without a grace period for unused amounts. It also allows excess funds from a termination distribution to be deposited into a compatible health flexible spending account or health reimbursement arrangement. Amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act.
